Fig. 1 XRD patterns of xV-TiO2-A, V2O5 and TiO2-A. Fig. 2 Raman spectra of xV-TiO2-A from 1100 to 800 cm−1 under 17% O2/Ar (60 mL min−1) flow at 300 °C. Fig. 3 51V MAS–NMR spectra of xV-TiO2-A. Fig. 4 TEM and STEM-EDS mapping of 4.5V-TiO2-A. Fig. 5 (a) IR spectra of saturated adsorbed pyridine under Ar (60 mL min−1) flow at 150 °C and (b) the number of Lewis and Brønsted acid sites calculated from 1446 and 1537 cm−1 IR band areas. Fig. 6 C3H6 oxidation rate over xV-TiO2-A catalysts at 300 °C under a flow of 1000 ppm of NO, 1000 ppm of C3H6, 4000 ppm of CO, 6000 ppm of O2, and balance Ar (60 mL min−1). The catalyst amount was adjusted for C3H6 conversion to be 30% or less. Fig. 7 Temperature dependence of (a) C3H6, (b) CO and (c) NO conversion and (d) N2 yield under a flow of 1000 ppm of NO, 1000 ppm of C3H6, 4000 ppm of CO, 6000 ppm of O2, and balance Ar (60 mL min−1). The catalyst amount was 35.0 mg (the tandem catalyst and 1 wt% Rh/ZrO2), or 17.5 mg (5 wt% Cu/CeO2). Fig. 8 IR spectra under a flow of 1000 ppm of C3H6, 6000 ppm of O2, and balance Ar (60 mL min−1) at 300 °C. Fig. 9 Time course of absorbance of νas (COO) at 300 °C. (a) Formation under a flow of 1000 ppm of C3H6 and 6000 ppm of O2, and (b) consumption in a flow of 6000 ppm of O2 after saturated adsorption. Fig. 10 Correlation between C3H6 oxidation rate and the number of Brønsted acid sites. Fig. 11 Correlation between C3H6 oxidation rate and the number of Brønsted acid sites over various supported vanadia catalysts. Graduate School of Engineering Nagoya University Nagoya 464-8603 Japan Graphical abstract A tandem catalyst composed of V2O5/TiO2 (anatase, 8.5 V nm−2) for preferential oxidation of C3H6 in copresence of CO and Cu/CeO2 for NOCO reaction showed comparable three-way catalytic activity with Rh/ZrO2. For the design of a high-performance platinum group metal-free three-way catalyst, we propose a new C3H6-preferential oxidation (C3H6-PROX) catalyst under stoichiometric automobile exhaust gas (NOCOC3H6 O2) using supported vanadia catalysts. Among various V2O5 supported catalysts, V2O5/TiO2 (anatase, coverage of around one monolayer) showed the best activity for C3H6-PROX with preferable formation of CO. The tandem catalyst combination using V2O5/TiO2 as the upstream C3H6-PROX catalyst and Cu/CeO2 as the downstream NOCO reaction catalyst showed comparable activity for NO reduction as a Rh/ZrO2 catalyst. The reaction mechanism of C3H6 oxidation was analyzed using in situ Infrared spectroscopy. The C3H6 oxidation progressed with the formation of surface acetate as an intermediate, and acetate consumption was the key step of C3H6 oxidation. It is suggested that the Brønsted acid promoted the cleavage of the CC bond of acetate, therefore, the number of Brønsted acid sites is one of the critical factors for the higher performance of C3H6-PROX catalysts. Keywords Preferential oxidation of hydrocarbon Platinum group metal-free three-way catalyst Supported vanadia Brønsted acid 1 Introduction Platinum group metals (PGMs) are used in the three-way catalysts (TWCs) for detoxifying NOx, CO, and hydrocarbons (HC), such as propene (C3H6), in automobile exhaust gas. Although PGM-based catalysts show very high TWC performance and high stability, PGMs are expensive due to their limited resources. Therefore, a PGM-free TWC is required. Several groups have sought to develop base-metal TWCs [1–8], but there are few reports of base-metal catalysts that exhibit sufficient NOx reduction activity in the low-temperature range of around 300 °C. We reported that the NOCO reaction was more likely to proceed at lower C3H6 concentrations on NiFe2O4 [9] because the adsorbed species derived from the partial oxidation of C3H6 poison the catalyst surface and inhibit the NOCO reaction. To solve this problem, we developed a tandem catalyst composed of a catalyst for C3H6 preferential oxidation (C3H6-PROX) upstream and one for NO reduction by CO downstream [10]. For the upstream C3H6-PROX catalyst, a high C3H6 oxidation activity is required while suppressing the CO oxidation. A tandem catalyst using ZnCr2O4 as the C3H6-PROX catalyst and Cu/CeO2 as the NOCOO2 catalyst exhibited a high NO reduction activity and a N2 yield comparable with a Rh/ZrO2 catalyst. This is the first example of a PGM-free TWC that showed an activity comparable with PGM catalysts. However, ZnCr2O4 has a problem that it may leak highly toxic Cr6+. In addition, as far as we know, there are no reports on C3H6-PROX under co-existence with CO, so the descriptor of activity and preferentiality of C3H6 oxidation is unclear. To develop a C3H6-PROX catalyst with a higher performance, it is necessary to obtain a catalyst design guideline by revealing the descriptor of oxidation activity and the preferentiality of C3H6. Considering that in recent fuel-economy engines the exhaust gas temperature is significantly decreased, it is expected that the restriction on catalyst materials for next-generation automobiles will be relaxed. So far, a considerable number of supported vanadia catalysts have been suggested for CC and CH activation, such as partial oxidation [11–14] and oxidative dehydrogenation (ODH) [15–17] reactions. The strong effect of support materials on the structure and catalytic performance has been suggested experimentally and theoretically. Depending on the surface V density, the supported vanadia shows different structures, i.e., two-dimensional (2-D) monomeric and oligomeric species and three-dimensional (3-D) nanoparticles [18]. The propane ODH rate increased with increasing V density, but decreased with further increase in V density because of crystalline V2O5 evolution [19]. Furthermore, the redox property of the supported vanadia can be tuned by the local structure of the V species as well as the support. In the partial oxidation of propene to acrolein, the turnver frequencies (TOF) based on acrolein formation changed by about 10–100 times with the specific support [12]. This enhancement was attributed to the electronegativity of the support, which controlled the electron density on the bridging VOsupport bond available for redox reactions [12]. The acid property on vanadia can also be modified by supports. V2O5/TiO2 (anatase) presented a high density of acid sites, and their strength was as high as that on zeolites [20]. Therefore, V2O5/TiO2 (anatase) enabled the selective oxidation of propane efficiently. The supported vanadia catalyst can be expected to be a highly active catalyst for the C3H6-PROX by using a suitable support metal oxide and V loading amount. Although the cleavage of the allylic CH bond is an important step for the partial oxidation and dehydrogenation on metal oxide catalysts [21], further conversion of oxygenated hydrocarbons is required for C3H6-PROX. The effective feature of V2O5 for C3H6-PROX activity is expected to be different from that for the partial oxidation and dehydrogenation. In this study, we investigated a catalyst that preferentially oxidizes C3H6 to CO/CO2 at a high conversion under automobile exhaust gas conditions. To provide catalyst design guidelines, in situ infrared (IR) measurements were performed to identify key steps during the C3H6 oxidation reaction, and the critical factors for higher performance C3H6-PROX catalysts were clarified. 2 Experimental methods 2.1 Catalyst preparation The supported vanadia catalysts were prepared using a conventional impregnation method. NH4VO3 (purity 99%, Kishida Chemical Co., Ltd, Japan) was dissolved in 50 mL of distilled water with oxalic acid (purity 98%, Kishida Chemical Co., Ltd) to achieve complete dissolution (oxalic acid/NH4VO3 = 2.2 M ratio). The aqueous V solution was impregnated to support materials and stirred for 1 h. TiO2-A (anatase, JRC-TIO-7), TiO2-R (rutile, JRC-TIO-16), CeO2 (JRC-CEO-3), and ZrO2 (JRC-ZRO-3) were Japan Reference Catalyst (JRC) supplied from the committee of reference catalyst, Catalysis Society of Japan. Al2O3 (AKP-G07) was purchased from Sumitomo Chemical Co. Ltd. Usually, 1.0 g of catalyst was prepared. Excess water was removed in a rotary evaporator (500 mL of rotary flask capacity) at 60 °C. Next, the obtained solid was dried at 80 °C to be a smooth powder and calcined at 400 °C for 4 h in air. The supports were precalcined at 500 °C for 1 h in air. The catalysts were named xV-MOx or xV-TiO2-A*. The indexes ×, MOx, and * imply the density of surface V atoms (V nm−2), support materials, and the use of uncalcined TiO2, respectively. The density of surface V atoms was calculated using the following equation. v a n a d i u m d e n s i t y V n m - 2 = n u m b e r o f v a n a d i u m a t o m s s u r f a c e a r e a o f s u p p o r t s ( n m 2 ) Catalysts of 5 wt% Cu/CeO2 and 1 wt% Rh/ZrO2 were prepared using a conventional impregnation method with aqueous solutions of copper (II) nitrate (purity 95%, Kishida Chemical Co., Ltd) and rhodium (III) nitrate, n-hydrate (35.36%, Kishida Chemical Co., Ltd), respectively. The aqueous nitrate solutions were impregnated with CeO2 (JRC-CEO-3) or ZrO2 (JRC-ZRO-3) followed by evaporation of excess water at 60 °C, drying at 80 °C, and finally calcination at 500 °C for 3 h in air. 2.2 Activity test The catalytic activity was evaluated using a fixed bed reactor. Catalyst (17.5 mg) was placed into a U-shaped quartz tube with 4 mm inner diameter and 150 mm length. A model exhaust gas at stoichiometric composition (1000 ppm of NO, 1000 ppm of C3H6, 4000 ppm of CO, 6000 ppm of O2, and balance Ar) was fed to the catalysts with the total flow rate of 60 mL min−1 (gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) ≈ 200,000 mL g−1 h−1). The gas cylinders were supplied by Taiyo Nippon Sanso JFP Corporation, as 1.02% NO/Ar, 1.01% C3H6/Ar, 4.99% CO/Ar, 2.99% O2/Ar, and pure Ar (99.995％). The catalysts were pretreated in a flow of 6000 ppm O2/Ar at 400 °C for 15 min. The activity test was carried out from 200 to 400 °C in 50 °C increments. The steady-state activity was measured using a multigas analyzer (HORIBA VA-3003 and VS-3004) for NO/CO/CO2 and a gas chromatograph (Agilent Model 490 Micro GC, equipped with MS-5A and PoraPLOT Q columns, and a thermal conductivity detector (TCD)) for C3H6 and N2O. The conversions of NO, CO, and C3H6 were estimated using the following equations. N O c o n v e r s i o n % = N O i n - N O o u t N O i n × 100 C O c o n v e r s i o n % = CO ( i n ) - C O ( o u t ) CO ( i n ) × 100 C 3 H 6 c o n v e r s i o n % = C 3 H 6 ( i n ) - C 3 H 6 ( o u t ) C 3 H 6 ( i n ) × 100 N2 yield was calculated by following equation. N 2 y i e l d % = N O i n - N O o u t - 2 N 2 O o u t N O i n × 100 C3H6 oxidation rate was estimated by the following equation. C 3 H 6 o x i d a t i o n r a t e m o l s - 1 m - 2 = t o t a l f l o w r a t e L s - 1 × C 3 H 6 c o n v e r s i o n s u r f a c e a r e a m 2 g - 1 × c a t a l y s t a m o u n t ( g ) × 22.4 ( L mol - 1 ) 2.3 N2 Adsorption measurements The specific surface area was evaluated from a N2 adsorption isotherm at −196 °C using a BELSORP-mini II (MicrotracBEL Co. Ltd., Japan) instrument. Before measurement, about 100 mg catalyst was pretreated at 300 °C for 30 min under vacuum. The surface area was calculated using the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) multipoint method. 2.4 X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements The XRD patterns were measured using a Rigaku Multiflex II /AP apparatus with Cu Kα radiation (30 kV, 15 mA). The patterns were taken in the range of 20° ≤ 2θ ≤ 80° with a scan speed of 1° min−1. 2.5 Raman spectroscopy Raman spectra were measured using a JASCO RMP-330 (JASCO Corporation, Japan) instrument with a Peltier cooled charge–coupled device detector using a visible laser (λ = 532 nm). The sample was filled in a JASCO-DR600 vacuum heating diffusive reflection in situ cell with a sample pan of 0.5 mm thickness. The catalysts were pretreated in a flow of 1000 ppm of C3H6, 17% of O2, and balance Ar at 400 °C for 15 min. After the treatment, the catalysts were treated with 17% O2/Ar at 400 °C for 15 min to desorb the surface moisture. The center wavenumber of the measurement was 750 cm−1, and the measurement was performed five times in total with an exposure time of 30 s. 2.6 51V magic angle spin (MAS) nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) measurements 51V MAS–NMR measurements were performed on an 800 MHz wide-bore solid-state NMR spectrometer (JNM-ECZ800R, JEOL Ltd, Japan), operating at a magnetic field of 18.79 T. The corresponding 51V Larmor frequency is 210.46 MHz. A sample was sealed in a ZrO2 rotor of 1 mm diameter and spun at a rate of 60 kHz. All spectra were collected using the Oldfield echo sequence for which the interval time (τ) was synchronized with the rotor spinning frequency [22]. The Oldfield echo sequence was determined by the following equation, O l d f i e l d e c h o s e q u e n c e = p w - τ - 2 p w - τ - a c q where pw, τ, and acq represent the pulse width, interval time, and acquisition time, respectively. In this sequence, pw was 1 µs which is 1/4 of the π/2 pulse width for VOCl3 aqueous solution, and the recycle delay time of 0.2 sec were applied. Single pulse NMR experiments were conducted with a π/2 pulse width of 4.0 µs, a delay time of 0.2 s and an acquisition time of 0.655 ms. The chemical shifts were referenced to 0 ppm of the external VOCl3 aqueous solution. 2.7 Transmission electron microscopy (TEM), scanning TEM (STEM), and energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) TEM images and STEM-EDS mapping were obtained on a JEOL JEM-2100F microscope at an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. The sample was prepared by dropping methanol suspensions of the pretreated catalyst onto carbon grids. 2.8 Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) measurements FT-IR measurements were carried out using a JASCO FT/IR-6100 (JASCO Corporation) instrument. A 62.5 mg sample was formed into a 20 nm diameter pellet and mounted in a quartz IR cell with CaF2 windows. Spectra were measured between 1000 and 4000 cm−1 at a resolution of 4 cm−1. Before obtaining the spectra, a sample was pretreated in the same manner as for the activity tests. The background of IR spectra was obtained under Ar flow (60 mL min−1). IR spectra of adsorbed pyridine were obtained under Ar flow (about 60 mL min−1) at 150 °C after the introduction of pyridine until saturated–adsorption and purging physically adsorbed pyridine for 30–150 min. The gas line between the pyridine inlet and the in situ cell was heated at 150 °C. In situ IR spectra of adsorbed species under the reaction conditions were measured under a flow of 1000 ppm of C3H6, 6000 ppm of O2, and balance Ar at 300 °C, to focus on the role of C3H6-PROX on the upstream catalyst. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterizations Table 1 shows the profiles of supported vanadia catalysts used in this study. The catalysts were named xV-TiO2-A, where x represents the V atom density (V nm−2), defined as the number of V atoms per surface area (nm2) of TiO2. The surface area of TiO2 after precalcination at 500 °C was 101 m2 g−1, and that of uncalcined TiO2 (marked by adding *) was 137 m2 g−1. The vanadium atom densities of all the samples were under monolayer coverage (8–9 V nm−2) [23]. The surface areas of the samples using precalcined TiO2 were around 80 m2 g−1. The surface area of 8.5 V-TiO2-A* (120 m2 g−1) was larger than those of precalcined TiO2 supported catalysts. Fig. 1 shows XRD patterns of xV-TiO2-A. The observed XRD lines were at 2θ = 25.4°, 37.9°, 48.1°, 54.1°, 55.2°, 62.7°, 69.0°, 70.2°, and 75.1°. These lines are assigned to anatase-structure TiO2 [24]. The main diffraction lines of crystalline V2O5 at 20.6°, 26.3°, and 31.1° were not observed in the XRD patterns [25]. Fig. 2 shows Raman spectra in the range of 1100–800 cm−1. In 1.5 V-TiO2-A, the band attributed to the VO bond of vanadia was observed at 1021 cm−1, which is assignable to monomer vanadia species [26]. With the increase in V atom density, the band shifted to a higher wavenumber, indicating oligomerization of surface vanadia species. The band derived from crystalline V2O5 at 996 cm−1 was not observed [27], which agreed with the XRD results. The bridging VOV polymerized mode at 900–940 cm−1 was not clear. These results are reasonable because the theoretical monolayer density of a V atom is 8–9 V nm−2 [23], and crystalline V2O5 is generated above monolayer coverage. Fig. S1 shows the XRD pattern and Raman spectrum of 11 V-TiO2-A. Crystalline V2O5 was observed in both the XRD pattern and Raman spectrum. 8.5 V-TiO2-A* was prepared using TiO2-A without calcination, which resulted in a high specific surface area and a higher vanadium loading without forming crystalline V2O5. For 8.5 V-TiO2-A*, the presence of crystalline V2O5 was not confirmed in both the XRD pattern and Raman spectrum. For a more detailed structural analysis of vanadium species, 51V MAS–NMR measurements were performed (Fig. 3 ). In the 51V NMR spectra, resonance peaks are observed at −490 and −533 ppm for monomer species, −570 and −630 ppm for dimer species, −580 and −645 ppm for oligomer species, and −615 ppm for V2O5-like large oligomers [28,29]. For 1.5 V-TiO2-A, resonance peaks at −490 and −534 ppm for monomer species and those at −570 ppm and −625 ppm for dimer species were observed. Peaks ascribable to monomer species (−534 ppm), dimer species (−571 ppm), V2O5-like large oligomers (−614 ppm) and oligomer species (−644 ppm) were detected in 4.5 V-TiO2-A. For 8.5 V-TiO2-A, the NMR spectrum exhibited dimer species (−573 and −587 ppm), V2O5-like large oligomers (−615 ppm) and oligomer species (−642 ppm). For 8.5 V-TiO2-A*, peaks assigned to monomer species (−537 ppm), dimer species (−573 ppm), V2O5-like large oligomers (−615 ppm) and oligomer species (−645 ppm) were observed. The absence of 3-D V2O5 species in these catalysts was supported by XRD and Raman spectroscopy results. Therefore, the presence of a 2-D vanadia oligomer on these catalysts was suggested. The surface vanadia species oligomerized as the V atom density increased. TEM and STEM-EDS mapping measurements were performed to confirm V dispersion. TEM and STEM-EDS mapping images of 4.5 V-TiO2-A are shown in Fig. 4 . No crystalline V2O5 particle was detected in the TEM image. STEM-EDS mapping revealed that V atoms were well dispersed on TiO2. The number of acid sites on the catalysts was quantified by IR measurements using pyridine as a probe molecule. The IR spectra of adsorbed pyridine at 150 °C are shown in Fig. 5 (a). The bands of pyridinium ions (PyH+) adsorbed on Brønsted acid sites are observed at 1637 (ν8a) and 1537 cm−1 (ν19b) [30]. The bands of pyridine adsorbed on Lewis acid sites are observed at 1610 (ν8a) and 1445 cm−1 (ν19b). The number of acid sites per surface area was estimated from the band area of Brønsted acid at 1537 cm−1 and Lewis acid at 1446 cm−1 (Fig. 5 (b)). The extinction coefficients used in this study were 1.23 and 1.73 cm µmol−1 for the bands at 1537 cm−1 and 1446 cm−1, respectively [30]. The total number of acid sites was almost the same, and the proportion of Brønsted acid was high except for 1.5 V-TiO2-A. The IR spectra of pyridine adsorbed on a bare TiO2-A are shown in Fig. S2. In the case of TiO2 alone, only the bands of Lewis acid sites were observed. Therefore, Brønsted acid sites on xV-TiO2-A catalysts are derived from V species. The good spreading of 2-D vanadia on anatase support is well known because of a good crystallographic fitting [31]. The good efficiency of the Brønsted acid formation can be attributed to the good spreading of 2-D vanadia oligomer on anatase. 3.2 Activity tests The performance required for the C3H6-PROX catalyst is to oxidize C3H6 preferentially with high conversion in coexistence with CO without CO oxidation. This is because the role of the upstream catalyst is to remove C3H6 derivatives of which act as catalyst poison for the downstream catalyst, at the same time, the upstream catalyst should send CO downstream as a reductant of NO. C3H6 does not need to be completely oxidized to CO2, and even when it is converted to CO, the catalyst poisoning can be avoided and this is advantageous for NO reduction by CO over the downstream catalyst. The temperature dependence of the outlet concentrations of C3H6 and CO over xV-TiO2-A catalysts is shown in Fig. S3. The lower concentration of C3H6 means a higher C3H6 oxidation activity. When the outlet CO concentration is equivalent to the feed gas concentration (4000 ppm), the catalyst is inactive for CO oxidation. When the CO concentration exceeded 4000 ppm, it means that a part of C3H6 was partially oxidized to CO. The xV-TiO2-A catalysts preferentially oxidized C3H6 to CO under NOCOC3H6 O2 conditions. The C3H6 conversion and the outlet CO concentration became higher with the increase in V density to monolayer coverage. The competitive reactions over the supported vanadia catalyst were investigated. The effect of the copresence of CO on C3H6 oxidation activity is shown in Fig. S4 (a). The conversion of C3H6 was not much affected by the presence of CO. By contrast, the CO oxidation activity was strongly affected by the copresence of C3H6. The CO2 production for the COO2 reaction was much stronger than that of the C3H6 COO2 reaction, despite the latter including the contribution of C3H6 oxidation to CO2 (Fig. S4(b)). The series of vanadia catalysts showed no catalytic activity for NO reduction in the presence of NOC3H6 COO2 (figure not shown). Therefore, we focused on the oxidation activity of C3H6. The oxidation rate of C3H6 per surface area at 300 °C as an index of C3H6 oxidation activity is shown in Fig. 6 . To exclude the effects of diffusion of substrates and heat generation, the oxidation rate was measured when the C3H6 conversion was 30% or less by adjusting the amount of catalyst. The C3H6 oxidation rate per surface area of xV-TiO2-A catalysts became higher as the V atom density increased up to 8.5 V atom nm−2. Further increase in V atom density decreased the C3H6 oxidation rate (Fig. S5, 11 V-TiO2-A). This is because of the formation of crystalline V2O5 (Fig. S1). The C3H6 oxidation activity on 3-D V2O5 crystals above monolayer coverage was lower than that of monomer and oligomer. As far as 2-D vanadia species are formed, turnover frequencies (TOF, C3H6 oxidation rate/V atom) for the C3H6 oxidation were in the range of 1.7–2.7 × 10−3 s−1. The highest C3H6 oxidation rate per surface area was obtained on 8.5 V-TiO2-A*, which had the largest amount of supported vanadia without crystalline V2O5 (Fig. 6). The highest TOF at 300 °C was observed for 8.5 V-TiO2-A* (Fig. S6). This value is lower than that for selective oxidation. Zhao et al. reported that 3 wt% V2O5/TiO2 (4.5 V atom nm−2) showed a TOF of 12 × 10−3 s−1 for the oxidation of C3H6 to acrolein [32]. The lower TOF for C3H6-PROX should be caused by very low substrate concentration in C3H6-PROX (C3H6/O2 = 1000 ppm/6000 ppm) than that for the selective oxidation (C3H6/O2 = 10vol%/40 vol%). We examined the activity of supported V catalysts on different supports. Al2O3, Co3O4, Fe2O3, In2O3, MgO, Nb2O3, SiO2, SnO2, TiO2-A (anatase), TiO2-R (rutile), and ZrO2 were investigated as the supports. The outlet concentrations of C3H6 and CO over various supported vanadia catalysts (4.5 V nm−2) at 300 °C are shown in Fig. S7. 4.5 V-Co3O4 showed the highest C3H6 oxidation activity, but it almost completely oxidized CO to CO2. 4.5V-TiO2-A showed comparable activity for C3H6 oxidation as 4.5V-Co3O4, while the CO concentration remained unchanged. That is, TiO2-A is the most suitable material as the support metal oxide for the C3H6-PROX catalyst. An automotive exhaust contains water vapor derived from the combustion of hydrocarbons. When 3% of water vapor was added to the C3H6-PROX feed gas, the C3H6 conversion over 8.5V-TiO2-A* only slightly decreased and quickly recovered after the removal of water vapor (Fig. S8). The result indicated that the poisoning effect of water vapor on supported vanadia is reversible. Because 8.5V-TiO2-A* showed the highest C3H6 oxidation activity and sufficient preferentiality, we used it for the C3H6-PROX catalyst as an upstream tandem catalyst. The temperature dependence of C3H6, CO, and NO conversions, and N2 yield are shown in Fig. 7 . The samples are the tandem catalyst (8.5 V-TiO2-A* for C3H6-PROX and 5 wt% Cu/CeO2 for NOCOO2 reaction), 5 wt% Cu/CeO2, and 1 wt% Rh/ZrO2 served as a benchmark. The conversions of C3H6 and CO of the tandem catalyst were higher than for 1 wt% Rh/ZrO2 in the temperature range between 200 and 500 °C. The tandem catalyst using 8.5 V-TiO2-A* as the C3H6-PROX catalyst showed NO reduction activity and N2 yield comparable with the 1 wt% Rh/ZrO2. The NO reduction activity appeared at 300 °C at which C3H6 conversion reached nearly 90%. This result suggests that complete oxidation of C3H6 is required to convert NO in the downstream catalyst. The sufficient performance of the supported vanadia catalyst as a C3H6-PROX catalyst was confirmed, which was comparable with ZnCr2O4 [10]. 3.3 In situ IR measurements In situ IR measurements were performed to identify the key steps in C3H6 oxidation. The IR spectra under a flow of 1000 ppm of C3H6, 6000 ppm of O2, and Ar as balance at 300 °C are shown in Fig. 8 . The main bands at 1524 and 1441 cm−1 were assigned to ν as (COO) and ν s (COO) of acetate, respectively [33,34]. A weak band at 1613 cm−1, observed in 4.5 V-TiO2-A and 8.5 V-TiO2-A*, was assigned to ν (CC) of C3H6 [34]. A negative band at 1375 cm−1 was attributed to ν(CO) of residual carbonate that cannot be removed by pretreatment in a flow of O2/Ar. In situ IR measurements revealed that mainly acetate species are adsorbed on the catalysts under C3H6 oxidation. The response of the acetate ν as (COO) band intensity during the introduction of C3H6 in O2, followed by C3H6 cut off at 300 °C is shown in Fig. 9 (a and b). These responses were obtained from the time-resolved IR spectra (Fig. S9). The bands monotonically increased in a flow of C3H6 O2 and decreased in a flow of diluted O2. There was not much shift of the observed bands during the experiment. The response in Fig. 9 indicates the formation and consumption rates of acetate on the catalyst. These acetate rates were estimated by the initial slope of absorbance as a function of time. The formation rates were almost the same for all xV-TiO2-A catalysts. By contrast, the consumption rates were slower than the formation rates, and depended on the V atom density, and the rate increased as the V atom density increased. This result suggests that the C3H6 oxidation activity may depend on the acetate consumption rate. We performed a kinetic analysis to confirm the contribution of acetate oxidation to the key step of C3H6 oxidation. The acetate concentration was estimated using the following Lambert–Beer equation, A = ε C W S where A, ε, C, W, and S represent the absorbance, the extinction coefficient of CH3COO−, the concentration of CH3COO−, the weight of the catalyst, and the geometric area of the IR disk, respectively. The extinction coefficient was 0.27 cm µmol−1 for theν as (COO) band at 300 °C determined by an injection of acetic acid vapor onto the catalyst disk. The adsorbed amount of acetic acid was measured by the produced amount of CO and CO2 during the complete oxidation of adsorbed acetate in O2 at 400 °C. The extinction coefficient was determined by comparing the IR intensity of ν as (COO) band at 300 °C (Fig. S10) and adsorbed acetic acid amount. Acetate formation and consumption rates were measured by the slope of the dynamic change of acetate concentration (Fig. S11). Table 2 compares the formation and consumption rates of acetate measured from the time-resolved IR spectra and the rates of C3H6 oxidation measured from activity tests. The formation rates were faster than the rates of acetate consumption and C3H6 oxidation. By contrast, the rates of acetate consumption and C3H6 oxidation were fairly consistent, and both increased with the V atom density. To identify the key step in acetate oxidation, IR measurements were conducted with acetic acid and formic acid adsorbed. Analogously, the reactivity of formate was examined. The IR spectra and the CO and CO2 concentrations when formic acid vapor was injected are shown in Fig. S12(a and b), in comparison with acetic acid. After formic acid was introduced, the adsorbed species could not be observed, and the outlet CO concentration was higher than that when acetic acid was introduced. These results show the formic acid was immediately oxidized to CO over xV-TiO2-A. It was confirmed that the oxidation step via formate is faster than via acetate. These surface kinetic results indicate that acetate is the intermediate for C3H6 oxidation over xV-TiO2-A catalysts. The key role of acetate species in hydrocarbon oxidation is in harmony with previous reports [9,34,35]. Li et al. reported that formate and acetate were produced as intermediates in the C3H6 oxidation reaction over Co3O4-based catalysts [35]. They suggested that the desorption step of formate and acetate associated with the oxidation was the key step because of the dominant adsorption of these species at low temperatures (T < 250 °C). Zhang et al. reported the reaction mechanism of the complete oxidation reaction of C3H6 over YMn2O5 [34]. C3H6 was adsorbed on YMn2O5 with the cleavage of the CC bond, and formate and acetate were generated as the intermediates. These previous reports support that the CC cleavage is the key step of acetate oxidation. 3.4 The contribution of Brønsted acid to C3H6 oxidation activity What is the descriptor of the consumption rate of acetate and the oxidation rate of C3H6? A positive correlation was found between the C3H6 oxidation rate and the number of Brønsted acid sites (Fig. 10 ). Brønsted acid is known to be the active species for cleavage of CC bonds [36] and it is expected to play an important role in the C3H6 oxidation reaction because that also requires cleavage of the CC bond in the oxidation of acetate. The dependence of the C3H6 oxidation rate on the number of Brønsted acid sites indicates that the CC cleavage of acetate is the key step in C3H6 oxidation. The same trend was also observed not only in TiO2-A supports, but also in other supports (Al2O3, CeO2, TiO2-R (rutile), and ZrO2), for which the experimental data and the preparation procedure are shown in the supporting information (Figs. S14–20 and Table S2). The C3H6 oxidation rates of all the supported vanadia catalysts were correlated with the number of Brønsted acid sites (Fig. 11 ). Fig. S13 shows the correlation between TOF (C3H6 oxidation rate/V atom) and the Brønsted acid fraction per V atom, calculated from the adsorbed amount of pyridinium ion (PyH+). The higher the number of Brønsted acid sites, the higher the C3H6 oxidation activity per V atom. These results support that the Brønsted acid is the descriptor for C3H6 oxidation over vanadia catalysts. The partial oxidation of C3H6 starts from cleavage of allylic CH bonds followed by the formation of a π-allyl complex [21], then oxygenated hydrocarbon is produced. For the C3H6-PROX catalysts, further conversion of the oxygenated hydrocarbon to CO or CO2 is required. The surface kinetic analysis by in-situ FT-IR demonstrated that the conversion of oxygenated hydrocarbon, i.e., surface acetate, is the rate-determining step for further oxidation. For further oxidation of acetate, the presence of Brønsted acid is necessary for the cleavage of the CC bond (Figs. 10 and 11). Different from the selective oxidation, it was found that this is the unique point of the use of supported V2O5 catalyst for C3H6-PROX. 4 Conclusions In this study, we successfully demonstrated the use of a new C3H6-PROX catalyst using supported vanadia, providing a catalyst design guideline. 8.5 V-TiO2-A* showed high C3H6 conversion and preferentiality. When it was combined with a NOCOO2 catalyst (Cu/CeO2) in a tandem layout, the tandem catalyst showed very high NO reduction activity and N2 selectivity comparable with precious metal catalysts. In situ IR measurements revealed that adsorbed acetate is the intermediate for C3H6 oxidation, and the acetate oxidation process is the key step of C3H6 oxidation. The positive correlation between the C3H6 oxidation rate and the number of Brønsted acid sites showed that the latter is the descriptor of the catalytic activity of supported vanadia catalysts. Therefore, the production of a large number of Brønsted acid sites on vanadia is a design guideline for the development of higher performance C3H6-PROX catalysts. coredata.dc:description: For the design of a high-performance platinum group metal-free three-way catalyst, we propose a new C3H6-preferential oxidation (C3H6-PROX) catalyst under stoichiometric automobile exhaust gas (NOCOC3H6 O2) using supported vanadia catalysts. Among various V2O5 supported catalysts, V2O5/TiO2 (anatase, coverage of around one monolayer) showed the best activity for C3H6-PROX with preferable formation of CO. The tandem catalyst combination using V2O5/TiO2 as the upstream C3H6-PROX catalyst and Cu/CeO2 as the downstream NOCO reaction catalyst showed comparable activity for NO reduction as a Rh/ZrO2 catalyst. The reaction mechanism of C3H6 oxidation was analyzed using in situ Infrared spectroscopy. The C3H6 oxidation progressed with the formation of surface acetate as an intermediate, and acetate consumption was the key step of C3H6 oxidation. It is suggested that the Brønsted acid promoted the cleavage of the CC bond of acetate, therefore, the number of Brønsted acid sites is one of the critical factors for the higher performance of C3H6-PROX catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Preferential oxidation of propene in gasoline exhaust conditions over supported vanadia catalysts
